name: sys::pal::unix::stack_overflow::imp::get_stack_start

core::mem::MaybeUninit::<T>::uninit.doc:
Creates a new `MaybeUninit<T>` in an uninitialized state.

 Note that dropping a `MaybeUninit<T>` will never call `T`'s drop code.
 It is your responsibility to make sure `T` gets dropped if it got initialized.

 See the [type-level documentation][MaybeUninit] for some examples.

 # Example

 ```
 use std::mem::MaybeUninit;

 let v: MaybeUninit<String> = MaybeUninit::uninit();
 ```

core::ptr::null_mut.doc:
Creates a null mutable raw pointer.

 This function is equivalent to zero-initializing the pointer:
 `MaybeUninit::<*mut T>::zeroed().assume_init()`.
 The resulting pointer has the address 0.

 # Examples

 ```
 use std::ptr;

 let p: *mut i32 = ptr::null_mut();
 assert!(p.is_null());
 assert_eq!(p as usize, 0); // this pointer has the address 0
 ```
